I sometimes use a Bluetooth mouse for phone vnc connections and while the mouse overlay is hidable with the cursor functioning as if it mouse directly connected to the computer the cursor still bumps the screen around. content: Very handy app, allows access to my Raspberry Pi from my tablet. You have to get used to the mouse, and the desktop shifts around unexpectedly. I see the latest update addressed this, which I'll have to check out. My main complaint is the app often stops working when I have minimized it, looked at my browser, and then come back to the app. It's easy to reopen it, but it is an interruption when you're trying to get something done. Overall I really like the app and feel it's well worth the cost.
replyContent:
This is definitely inconvenient behavior.
We're going to improve that in the future updates.
Please, write us at android@glavsoft.com with details, it would help us a lot.
Thank you!

content: Auto quality doesn't seem to reduce when on mobile network and defaults to Ultra quality on LAN, when I need the higher frame rate of High. I sort of expected a TightVNC Viewer to be using Tight in most cases? In home use, the server PC is typically playing Youtube or Fortnite...

Sorry you have such bad experience with Remote Ripple.
Would you like to write us at android@glavsoft.com with details?

We definitely will consider the ability to add 256 colours to quality options in Remote Ripple.

Thanks!

content: it is not working with my mac . I tried both bVNC and VNCviewer, they both able to connect although terriblely slow graphic rendering. however, this tightVNC complains server send some unsuppored encrpytion and refuse to connect.
replyContent:
Please, write to us at android@glavsoft.com and we'll try solve the problem.
However, as far as I know, native macOS VNC Server supports only RAW encoding, so it is going to render on viewer slowly all the time. You should consider alternative VNC servers for macOS if want to improve performance. Thank you!
--
Edgar Letner,
GlavSoft LLC

Unable to connect to Raspberry Pi (installed version appears to be a version of Real VNC) returns error "No security types supported
replyContent:
You could try to install TightVNC server!
1. Log in to your Pi.
2. Type in the command line: ‚Äúsudo apt-get install tightvncserver‚Äù to
install TightVNC Server.
3. Run the program: ‚Äútightvncserver‚Äù
4. Start a VNC session: ‚Äúvncserver :1 -geometry 1024x728 -depth 24‚Äù
Anyway, please, write to us at android@glavsoft.com and we'll help with the problem.

Very easy and convenient to use. I'm using galaxy note pro 12.2. This application works flawlessly with tight vnc.

content: Good app, couple of small issues like constantly asking to rate it and letters typed are repeated but otherwise perfectly usable
Have used tight vnc for many years - this is a welcome addition.
been using for only couple of days now but till now it's a really great app, very useful smooth and responsive...
I found this to be a very useful and functional application. Well worth the money. I use it to monitor and control all of my networked systems. Try it.
No issues
I love this app! It is everything I could ask for in a mobile vnc client. I can't think of one improvement I would make to it.
Works pretty decently, though I wish there were more options for controlling the view on the remote computer, and some of the compression types fail when used from my phone LG G2 (d800).
Great
Excellent price. Very fast and responsive, good features. Works well even when your connection is slow due to range of settings you can apply.
Astronomer I can monitor my telescope from indoors so I can stay warm in the winter
For some reason I purchased this app twice over the past year. Phone reset but once I bought again the pro version was the same as the  free version. Now Its saying I don't own it again?
replyContent:
Please contact us at android@glavsoft.com, we'll be happy to fix this. It should be enough to pay just once!

-- 
Best Regards,
Constantin Kaplinsky,
GlavSoft LLC

content: Best remote operating app out there.
Simplicity at its best.
TightVNC has done an excellent job with this remote control app.
